messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Kelly, I ve been reading the messages on this list and feeling so relaxed.  I have not really been looking forward to this school year at all, and this
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Kelly, I've been reading the messages on this list and feeling so relaxed. I have not really been looking forward to this school year at all, and this list is really taking a lot off my shoulders. This should be fun. Steph
----- Original Message -----
From: kbcdlovejo@...
To: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 7:42 PM
Subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?


In a message dated 7/21/2003 7:03:57 PM Eastern Daylight Time,
stephc62@... writes:


> This sounds like an interesting post. LOL what is this and how can I read
> this myself? I need something to spark my days lately. Steph

Well, Steph---if you can handle the unschoolingdotcomedy---oops! Unschooling
Discusion List---it's there. She's already received a few nice suggestions.
(There's also been a spanking discussion going on there---so my snarky
comment here!<g>)

~Kelly

~Kelly

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?
messages.msgSnippet: ... The question was whether there were really people on the list who don t punish their children. I guess a simple, Yes, would have answered it . -pam
messages.messageBody:
On Monday, July 21, 2003, at 05:59 PM, Barb Eaton wrote:

> Whack a Troll. LOL! (I'm kidding for those that don't know me) I
> never
> did get a question in all that either Sandra.

The question was whether there were really people on the list who don't
punish their children. I guess a simple, "Yes," would have answered it
<BEG>.

-pam

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?
messages.msgSnippet: Whack a Troll. LOL! (I m kidding for those that don t know me) I never did get a question in all that either Sandra. I should have known better than read her
messages.messageBody:
Whack a Troll. LOL! (I'm kidding for those that don't know me) I never
did get a question in all that either Sandra. I should have known better
than read her posts. Now there are two I fly by in the digest. ;-)


Barb E
"The smartest thing that a person can do is to persistently think
the thoughts that are consistent with the kind of person he or she
would like to be."

- Brian Tracy, Author and Personal Development Expert




on 7/21/03 5:28 PM, kbcdlovejo@... at kbcdlovejo@... wrote:

> This is just for those of you on boths lists:
>
>
>> What kinds of things can I do, not coercive, but to help him, make better
>> decisions on his own. He feels badly after things like this, and I don't
>> think that guilt is helping him make better decisions.
>
> I'd just smack him one---he won't do it again!
>
> OK. I feel better! I kept it off the other list! <G>
>
> ~Kelly

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?
messages.msgSnippet: ** I d just smack him one---he won t do it again! OK. I feel better! I kept it off the other list! ** My snarky thought was spank the cats and that ll
messages.messageBody:
** I'd just smack him one---he won't do it again!

OK. I feel better! I kept it off the other list! <G>**

My snarky thought was "spank the cats and that'll teach them not to run
in the street."

end of sarcasm

Betsy

PS This is not aimed at Aimee. Sorry to disrespect her cats in the
service of snarkiness.

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?
messages.msgSnippet: This sounds like an interesting post.  LOL what is this and how can I read this myself?  I need something to spark my days lately.  Steph ... From:
messages.messageBody:
This sounds like an interesting post. LOL what is this and how can I read this myself? I need something to spark my days lately. Steph
----- Original Message -----
From: kbcdlovejo@...
To: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 5:28 PM
Subject: [AlwaysLearning] what should I do?


This is just for those of you on boths lists:


> What kinds of things can I do, not coercive, but to help him, make better
> decisions on his own. He feels badly after things like this, and I don't
> think that guilt is helping him make better decisions.

I'd just smack him one---he won't do it again!

OK. I feel better! I kept it off the other list! <G>

~Kelly

messages.messageBody:
This is just for those of you on boths lists:


> What kinds of things can I do, not coercive, but to help him, make better
> decisions on his own. He feels badly after things like this, and I don't
> think that guilt is helping him make better decisions.

I'd just smack him one---he won't do it again!

OK. I feel better! I kept it off the other list! <G>

~Kelly
